elements.content: A new terpyridine-inspired terdentate ligand, 4-(4-pyridyl)-2,5-dipyrazyl-pyridine (py-pzpypz), featuring three “spare” nitrogen donors “out the back”, has been used to synthesize five bis-ligand complexes, [MII(py-pzpypz)2]­X2, where M = Mn with X = ClO4, or M = Fe, Co, Ni, and Zn with X = BF4. In contrast, when M = CuII, regardless of the M:L ratio employed, 1:1 M:L products were obtained: for X = BF4 a 1D chain {[CuII(py-pzpypz)­(DMF)2]­(BF4)2} n , and for X = Cl a monometallic complex [Cu­(py-pzpypz)­Cl2]. All seven complexes were structurally characterized, confirming the expected N6 coordination of the MII centers in all cases except CuII. Notably, a Jahn–Teller elongation is observed in the CoII complex, consistent with it being low spin at 100 K. The CuII 1D chain complex has an N4O2 coordination sphere as in this case the “spare” pyridine donor out the back of the py-pzpypz ligand bridges to the next CuII center in the chain, hence providing both a terdentate site and a monodentate pyridine to the next CuII center, and the coordination sphere is completed by weak axial coordination by two DMF solvent molecules. The CuII center in the monometallic complex has an N3Cl2 square pyramidal coordination sphere. In all cases, the noncoordinating, “spare”, pyrazine nitrogen atoms are involved in interesting intermolecular interactions, including NPz–π interactions and nonclassical C–H···NPz hydrogen bonding. The FeII complex is low spin as expected. Two polymorphs of the CoII complex were obtained, both of which showed gradual spin crossover, with a room temperature T 1/2. Two reversible redox processes are observed for [CoII(py-pzpypz)2]­(BF4)2, with E m(MI/MII) = −0.63 V and E m(MII/MIII) = +0.37 V, and a quasireversible redox process for [FeII(py-pzpypz)2]­(BF4)2, with E m(MII/MIII) = +1.26 V, versus 0.01 M AgNO3/Ag in MeCN. These potentials are shifted to significantly higher potentials (by ∼0.45 V) than the literature values for the corresponding FeII and CoII complexes of the equivalent all-pyridine ligand, consistent with replacement of the two pyridine rings by two pyrazine rings significantly stabilizing the lower oxidation states.

The CuII 1D chain complex has an N4O2 coordination sphere as in this case the "spare" pyridine donor out the back of the py-pzpypz ligand bridges to the next CuII center in the chain, hence providing both a terdentate site and a monodentate pyridine to the next CuII center, and the coordination sphere is completed by weak axial coordination by two DMF solvent molecules. The CuII center in the monometallic complex has an N3Cl2 square pyramidal coordination sphere. In all cases, the noncoordinating, "spare", pyrazine nitrogen atoms are involved in interesting intermolecular interactions, including NPz-π interactions and nonclassical C-H⋅⋅⋅NPz hydrogen bonding. The FeII complex is low spin as expected. Two polymorphs of the CoII complex were obtained, both of which showed gradual spin crossover, with a room temperature T 1/2. elements.content: The structures of [ML2]­(BF4)2 complexes of the new terpyridine-inspired terdentate ligand, 4-(4-pyridyl)-2,5-dipyrazyl-pyridine, feature pyrazine lone-pair···pyrazine π intermolecular interactions (M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Zn). The cobalt­(II) and iron­(II) complexes exhibit reversible redox, and the cobalt­(II) complex undergoes spin crossover centered at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: The structures of [ML2](BF4)2 complexes of the new terpyridine-inspired terdentate ligand, 4-(4-pyridyl)-2,5-dipyrazyl-pyridine, feature pyrazine lone-pair⋅⋅⋅pyrazine π intermolecular interactions (M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Zn). The cobalt(II) and iron(II) complexes exhibit reversible redox, and the cobalt(II) complex undergoes spin crossover centered at room temperature.

elements.content: Terpyridine (L1, Figure ) was first prepared in 1932, but only after more user-friendly syntheses were developed did the chemistry of terpyridines accelerate, from a solid baseline of activity to publication rates growing almost exponentially since the 1990s. Transition metal complexes of terpyridine and related 4-substituted derivatives have been widely studied due to their interesting magnetic, optical, electrochemical, catalytic, and DNA binding properties. Focusing in further, to 3d complexes, spin crossover (SCO) in cobalt­(II) complexes of terpyridine and its derivatives is well-known, and in all but a few cases these are gradual and without a thermal hysteresis. Other examples of cobalt­(II) complexes of terpyridine derivatives (e.g., L5, Figure ) have shown interesting photochemical properties such as photocleavage of DNA. Ligands, like L5, which feature an additional donor within the 4-substituent “off the back” of the terpy moiety have also been used to explore the controlled formation of interesting supramolecular architectures. Iron­(II) complexes of terpyridine-like ligands are almost always low spin at room temperature (unless sterically hindered) but often show interesting reversible redox behavior.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Terpyridine (L1, Figure ) was first prepared in 1932, but only after more user-friendly syntheses were developed did the chemistry of terpyridines accelerate, from a solid baseline of activity to publication rates growing almost exponentially since the 1990s. Transition metal complexes of terpyridine and related 4-substituted derivatives have been widely studied due to their interesting magnetic, optical, electrochemical, catalytic, and DNA binding properties. Focusing in further, to 3d complexes, spin crossover (SCO) in cobalt(II) complexes of terpyridine and its derivatives is well-known, and in all but a few cases these are gradual and without a thermal hysteresis. Other examples of cobalt(II) complexes of terpyridine derivatives (e.g., L5, Figure ) have shown interesting photochemical properties such as photocleavage of DNA. Ligands, like L5, which feature an additional donor within the 4-substituent "off the back" of the terpy moiety have also been used to explore the controlled formation of interesting supramolecular architectures. Iron(II) complexes of terpyridine-like ligands are almost always low spin at room temperature (unless sterically hindered) but often show interesting reversible redox behavior.

elements.content: The pyrazine analogues of these terpyridine-type ligands have received far less attention (e.g., L2–L4, Figure ), with the replacement of one or more pyridine rings by pyrazine rings first reported by Plé and co-workers in 2005. These new pyrazine analogues are of interest to coordination chemists for two main reasons.
elements.clean_text: The pyrazine analogues of these terpyridine-type ligands have received far less attention (e.g., L2-L4, Figure ), with the replacement of one or more pyridine rings by pyrazine rings first reported by Plé and co-workers in 2005. These new pyrazine analogues are of interest to coordination chemists for two main reasons.

elements.content: First, the electronics are changed due to the weaker σ-donor and stronger π-acceptor nature of pyrazine which is generally expected to stabilize the low spin (LS) state and to increase the MII/MIII potential of the complex, relative to that of the pyridine analogue. With regard to the former expectation, intriguingly Halcrow and co-workers showed that replacing only the central pyridine of terpyridine (L1) by pyrazine, giving L3, resulted in essentially high spin (HS) complexes, [CoII(L3)2]­(BF4)2, whereas replacing either the two distal pyridine rings, giving L2, or all three pyridine rings, giving L4, resulted in predominantly low spin (LS) complexes, [CoII(Ln)2]­(BF4)2 with n = 2 or 4. In contrast, as expected, they observed an increase in MII/MIII potential (vs Fc/Fc+ in MeCN) on replacing pyridine rings by pyrazine rings: whereas the E 1/2(FeII/FeIII) for [FeII(L1)2]­(BF4)2 was +0.71 V, for the pyrazine L2–L4 analogues it was +0.95 to +1.36 V. Likewise, the E 1/2(CoII/CoIII) for [CoII(L1)2]­(BF4)2 was −0.13 V whereas for the L2–L4 analogues it was between +0.12 and +0.49 V.

Likewise, the E 1/2(CoII/CoIII) for [CoII(L1)2](BF4)2 was -0.13 V whereas for the L2-L4 analogues it was between +0.12 and +0.49 V.

elements.content: Second, replacement of one or more pyridine rings by pyrazine rings in these ligands results in “spare” nitrogen donors “out the back” of the ligand. This opens up the possibility of bridging to other metal centers and forming supramolecular arrays, something we have recently reported for some pyrazine imide ligands. Such assemblies are of considerable current interest for their applications in areas such as magnetism, gas adsorption, and heterogeneous catalysis.

elements.content: Here we report the two-step synthesis of a new 2,6-dipyrazyl-pyridine ligand (Figure , Scheme , py-pzpypz) and the mid-to-late first row transition metal complexes of it (MnII to ZnII). The structures and physical properties of these new complexes are described and compared to those of the better known terpyridine based analogues (Figure ).

elements.content:
The new ligand 4-(4-pyridyl)-2,5-dipyrazyl-pyridine (py-pzpypz) was synthesized in two straightforward steps from the commercially available reagents pyrazine and pyridine-4-carbaldehyde (Scheme ).

First, 2-acetylpyrazine was prepared in 45% yield from pyrazine, by the method previously reported by Minisci and co-workers. Then it was reacted with 0.5 equiv of pyridine-4-carbaldehyde using a method adapted from that reported by Constable and Thompson for L5. Rather than this being carried out in two separate steps as for L5, i.e., initially isolating the diketone (afforded by the 2:1 aldol condensation of 2-acetylpyrazine and pyridine-4-carbaldehyde with NaOH in EtOH/H2O), then cyclizing with NH4OAc in EtOH, it was found that for py-pzpypz the reaction could be carried out in one pot. This was achieved by simply stirring the reagents with NH4OH and KOH in MeOH/H2O, monitoring the reaction by 1H NMR spectroscopy. The reaction is complete within 24 h. Then more water is added and the product extracted into CHCl3 which is taken to dryness to give py-pzpypz as a pale yellow powder. As py-pzpypz has low solubility in acetone, any traces of the starting materials are easily removed with an acetone wash, to give analytically pure py-pzpypz, as a white powder in 59% yield.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Ligand Synthesis

The new ligand 4-(4-pyridyl)-2,5-dipyrazyl-pyridine (py-pzpypz) was synthesized in two straightforward steps from the commercially available reagents pyrazine and pyridine-4-carbaldehyde (Scheme ).

First, 2-acetylpyrazine was prepared in 45% yield from pyrazine, by the method previously reported by Minisci and co-workers. Then it was reacted with 0.5 equiv of pyridine-4-carbaldehyde using a method adapted from that reported by Constable and Thompson for L5. Rather than this being carried out in two separate steps as for L5, i.e., initially isolating the diketone (afforded by the 2:1 aldol condensation of 2-acetylpyrazine and pyridine-4-carbaldehyde with NaOH in EtOH/H2O), then cyclizing with NH4OAc in EtOH, it was found that for py-pzpypz the reaction could be carried out in one pot. This was achieved by simply stirring the reagents with NH4OH and KOH in MeOH/H2O, monitoring the reaction by 1H NMR spectroscopy. The reaction is complete within 24 h. Then more water is added and the product extracted into CHCl3 which is taken to dryness to give py-pzpypz as a pale yellow powder. As py-pzpypz has low solubility in acetone, any traces of the starting materials are easily removed with an acetone wash, to give analytically pure py-pzpypz, as a white powder in 59% yield.

elements.content: Analytically pure powder samples of three of the [MII(py-pzpypz)2]­(X)2 complexes, where M = Fe, Co, Zn and X = BF4, were precipitated immediately on adding a MeOH solution of MII(BF4)2 to a MeOH/CHCl3 solution of py-pzpypz, due to the low solubility of the complexes in this solvent mixture. This method could also be used to prepare the yellow MnII (X = ClO4) complex; however, better yields (50%) were obtained using the refluxing MeCN strategy adopted for NiII (see next paragraph). These FeII (dark purple), CoII (red), and ZnII (white) complexes are obtained in 48–81% yields. They are insoluble in most common solvents (H2O, MeOH, CHCl3, DCM), with the notable exception of MeCN.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [MII(py-pzpypz)](X)2 

Analytically pure powder samples of three of the [MII(py-pzpypz)2](X)2 complexes, where M = Fe, Co, Zn and X = BF4, were precipitated immediately on adding a MeOH solution of MII(BF4)2 to a MeOH/CHCl3 solution of py-pzpypz, due to the low solubility of the complexes in this solvent mixture. This method could also be used to prepare the yellow MnII (X = ClO4) complex; however, better yields (50%) were obtained using the refluxing MeCN strategy adopted for NiII (see next paragraph). These FeII (dark purple), CoII (red), and ZnII (white) complexes are obtained in 48-81% yields. They are insoluble in most common solvents (H2O, MeOH, CHCl3, DCM), with the notable exception of MeCN.

elements.content: When this rapid precipitation from MeOH/CHCl3 method was attempted for NiII with X = BF4, an impure yellow solid, that is not soluble in any of the above solvents, or in MeCN at room temperature (RT), formed. Therefore, an MeCN suspension of this impure yellow powder was refluxed until it became a golden solution. It remained a solution on cooling, so diethyl ether was vapor diffused into it, resulting in golden block shaped crystals of the desired octahedral complex [NiII(py-pzpypz)2]­(BF4)2. However, the yield is improved, and the synthesis simplified, by simply carrying out the reaction in boiling MeCN. Subsequent CHCl3 vapor diffusion into the concentrated MeCN reaction solution gives golden block crystals of [NiII(py-pzpypz)2]­(BF4)2 in 67% yield.
elements.clean_text: When this rapid precipitation from MeOH/CHCl3 method was attempted for NiII with X = BF4, an impure yellow solid, that is not soluble in any of the above solvents, or in MeCN at room temperature (RT), formed. Therefore, an MeCN suspension of this impure yellow powder was refluxed until it became a golden solution. It remained a solution on cooling, so diethyl ether was vapor diffused into it, resulting in golden block shaped crystals of the desired octahedral complex [NiII(py-pzpypz)2](BF4)2. However, the yield is improved, and the synthesis simplified, by simply carrying out the reaction in boiling MeCN. Subsequent CHCl3 vapor diffusion into the concentrated MeCN reaction solution gives golden block crystals of [NiII(py-pzpypz)2](BF4)2 in 67% yield.

elements.content: Similarly, when the 1:2 M:L reaction was attempted for CuII, specifically with copper­(II) tetrafluoroborate, in MeOH/CHCl3, an impure green solid rapidly precipitated. Subsequent recrystallization of this solid, by dissolution in DMF and then vapor diffusion of Et2O, resulted in green block shaped crystals of the 1D chain complex {[Cu­(py-pzpypz)­(DMF)2]­(BF4)2} n . Despite the 1:2 Cu:L reaction, the product is 1:1. It is not uncommon for CuII to prefer CuLX2 and 5-coordination, over CuL2 and 6-coordination, when L is a relatively rigid terdentate ligand (X = solvent or anion). Not surprisingly, this 1D chain could be deliberately made, in a better yield (46%) and more simply, by a 1:1 reaction of py-pzpypz and [Cu­(H2O)6]­(BF4)2 in DMF at RT, followed be vapor diffusion of Et2O into the reaction solution. Surprisingly, the 1:1 M:L reaction of copper­(II) nitrate and py-pzpypz under solvothermal conditions did not produce an analogous 1D chain but rather a mixture containing a few single crystals of mononuclear [Cu­(py-pzpypz)­Cl2]. This complex could be deliberately prepared in good yield (75%) by carefully layering a solution of copper chloride in methanol on a solution of py-pzpypz in a DCM/MeOH mixture.

Surprisingly, the 1:1 M:L reaction of copper(II) nitrate and py-pzpypz under solvothermal conditions did not produce an analogous 1D chain but rather a mixture containing a few single crystals of mononuclear [Cu(py-pzpypz)Cl2]. NMR Spectroscopy

The two diamagnetic complexes, [MII(py-pzpypz)2](BF4)2 with M = Fe and Zn, were also characterized by 1H NMR spectroscopy and the proton chemical shifts compared to those of the free ligand (Figure  and  Figure S3).

elements.content: The H3 proton, meta to the coordinated pyrazine nitrogen, is shifted slightly downfield in the zinc­(II) complex (+0.07 ppm), but upfield in the iron­(II) complex (−0.29 ppm), relative to the free ligand. The H2 proton, also meta to the coordinated pyrazine nitrogen, but pointing toward the outside of the complex, is shifted strongly upfield in both complexes, but more so in the iron­(II) complex (−1.42 ppm) than in the zinc­(II) complex (−0.88 ppm). The H1 proton, ortho to the coordinated pyrazine nitrogen atom, was almost unaffected by coordination to zinc­(II) but shifted significantly upfield in the iron­(II) complex (−0.43 ppm). These shifts are all consistent with stronger π-acceptor character in the bond between pyrazine and low spin iron­(II) than is the case for d10 zinc­(II).

elements.content: All seven complexes were structurally characterized, and the key structural information is summarized in Tables –. Single crystals of the free ligand, as a hydrochloride salt ( Figure S6), were grown by diffusion of HCl­(g) (from a 0.1 mol L–1 aqueous HCl solution) into a CHCl3 solution of py-pzpypz ( Table S3 and Figure S6). The protonation occurs at the monodentate pyridine site; a peak corresponding to this proton was present in the residual electron density map. This proton is involved in a strong hydrogen bond to the Cl– anion [N(6)–H···Cl(1) 3.022(2) Å, 169.5(1)°], providing further confirmation that it is present.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Characterization

All seven complexes were structurally characterized, and the key structural information is summarized in Tables -. Single crystals of the free ligand, as a hydrochloride salt ( Figure S6), were grown by diffusion of HCl(g) (from a 0.1 mol L-1 aqueous HCl solution) into a CHCl3 solution of py-pzpypz ( Table S3 and Figure S6). The protonation occurs at the monodentate pyridine site; a peak corresponding to this proton was present in the residual electron density map. This proton is involved in a strong hydrogen bond to the Cl- anion [N(6)-H⋅⋅⋅Cl(1) 3.022(2) Å, 169.5(1)°], providing further confirmation that it is present.

elements.content: Single crystals of two polymorphs of [Co­(py-pzpypz)2]­(BF4)2 could be grown, by vapor diffusion of either Et2O or CHCl3, into an MeCN solution of the complex. When CHCl3 was used as the antisolvent, crystals of the mixed solvate [Co­(py-pzpypz)2]­(BF4)2·MeCN·CHCl3 were obtained in the triclinic space group P1̅ (polymorph 1, Figure ), whereas when Et2O was used crystals of the solvent-free [Co­(py-pzpypz)2]­(BF4)2 were obtained in the monoclinic space group P21/n (polymorph 2, Figure ).
elements.clean_text: Single crystals of two polymorphs of [Co(py-pzpypz)2](BF4)2 could be grown, by vapor diffusion of either Et2O or CHCl3, into an MeCN solution of the complex. When CHCl3 was used as the antisolvent, crystals of the mixed solvate [Co(py-pzpypz)2](BF4)2⋅MeCN⋅CHCl3 were obtained in the triclinic space group P1̅ (polymorph 1, Figure ), whereas when Et2O was used crystals of the solvent-free [Co(py-pzpypz)2](BF4)2 were obtained in the monoclinic space group P21/n (polymorph 2, Figure ).

elements.content: In both polymorphs, at 100 K, the N6-coordinated cobalt­(II) center shows a clear Jahn–Teller distortion, with four short equatorial bonds, and two long axial Co–Npz bonds within one of the two terdentate ligands, consistent with the cobalt­(II) center being in the low spin state (average Co–Npz; ligand 1 = 2.156 Å vs ligand 2 = 1.987 Å). As is usual for terpyridine-type complexes (Table ), the two Co–N bonds to the central pyridine nitrogen donor of each of the terdentate py-pzpypz ligands are significantly shorter than all four of the distal Co–N bonds to the pyrazine nitrogen atoms (av Co–Npycentral = 1.900 Å vs av Co–Npzdistal = 2.072 Å).

As is usual for terpyridine-type complexes (Table ), the two Co-N bonds to the central pyridine nitrogen donor of each of the terdentate py-pzpypz ligands are significantly shorter than all four of the distal Co-N bonds to the pyrazine nitrogen atoms (av Co-Npycentral = 1.900 Å vs av Co-Npzdistal = 2.072 Å).

Data provided here is for polymorph 1.

For comparison, for the parent terpyridine complex [CoII(L1)2]­(BF4)2 in the HS state the average Co–Npycentral versus average Co–Npydistal is 2.038 versus 2.154 Å whereas for the LS state it is 1.909 versus 2.092 Å (Table ). The complex of the all-pyridine analogue of py-pzpypz, [CoII(L5)2]­(ClO4)2, also appears to be low spin at 100 K on the basis of the structural data (Table ), although no magnetic data or comment on the spin state was present in that paper, although there is a Jahn–Teller compression rather than the elongation which is usually observed for terpyridine-like complexes (Table ). One other notable exception is seen for the reverse spin crossover CoII complex of C14-terpy (where C14-terpy is 4′-tetradecyloxy-2,2′:6′,2″-terpyridine) (Table ). Consistent with these specific examples, a search of the CSD (version 5.36, Nov 2014), for cobalt­(II) bis-terpyridine based complexes, gave 78 hits (LS and HS) with overall averages of CoII–Ncentral = 1.955 Å versus av CoII–Ndistal = 2.108 Å.

elements.content: The two polymorphs show significantly different packing interactions (Figures and ). In the solvated polymorph, polymorph 1 (P1̅), offset π–π-stacking interactions between the pyrazine rings (N2 ring with N2′ ring; N4 ring with N4′ ring) result in 1D chains of the complexes (Figure and Table ). Additionally there appears to be a favorable interaction between the lone pair on one of the “spare” pyrazine nitrogen atoms on one complex (N2) and the π-deficient pyrazine ring of an adjacent complex (Figure ). This neutral e-rich atom to e-deficient aromatic ring interaction is akin to the acetonitrile lone-pair to π-deficient triazine ring interactions first noted by Gamez, Reedijk, and co-workers, and more recently expanded upon by a CSD survey of the interactions of various neutral e-rich species, including R≡N and RNR′, with a range of aromatic rings. The pyrazine N lone-pair to pyrazine centroid distances (Table ) are consistent with moderate lone-pair to π interactions. The chloroform molecule interacts weakly with one of the tetrafluoroborate anions [Cl3CH···F = 3.053(3) Å, 156.8(1)°]. Surprisingly, no significant interactions are observed for the 4-pyridyl nitrogen atoms in polymorph 1 (Figure S8).

The pyrazine N lone-pair to pyrazine centroid distances (Table ) are consistent with moderate lone-pair to π interactions. The chloroform molecule interacts weakly with one of the tetrafluoroborate anions [Cl3CH⋅⋅⋅F = 3.053(3) Å, 156.8(1)°]. Surprisingly, no significant interactions are observed for the 4-pyridyl nitrogen atoms in polymorph 1 (Figure S8).

The crystal of [CoII(py-pzpypz)2]­(BF4)2·MeCN·CHCl3 (polymorph 1) was also warmed up and collected at 265 K. At 265 K only a very small increase in cell volume was observed along with very slight increases in all three cell axes ( Table S1). A slight decrease in the two long bonds (Table ) was also observed, consistent with a very small decrease in Jahn–Teller distortion which would be expected for high spin Co­(II). It is important to note that at this temperature the magnetic data suggests the sample is only approximately 30% HS, so it is unsurprising that the differences from the 100 K data set are slight.

elements.content: The π-stacking interactions are weakened in the solvent-free polymorph 2 (P21/n) such that the closest contact is now N4···C3A (3.247(5) Å, Figure S8). In this polymorph a bifurcated nonclassical C–H···N hydrogen bond is observed between one of the 4-pyridyl nitrogen atoms and two pyrazine C–H protons on an adjacent complex (Figure ; C(21)–H···N(26) = 3.153(5) Å, 133.0(2)°; C(22)–H···N(26) = 3.335(5), 116.7(3)°]. The other 4-pyridyl nitrogen is involved in a single nonclassical hydrogen bond [C(37)–H···N(6) = 3.149(5) Å, 144.3(3)°]. Together these nonclassical H-bonds result in a 1D chain of complexes (Figure ). The Co···Co separation along the chain in polymorph 2 is 8.920 Å whereas it was 8.717 Å in polymorph 1. Interestingly, no pyrazine lone-pair···π interactions are observed in polymorph 2 ( Figure S8).

In this polymorph a bifurcated nonclassical C-H⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen bond is observed between one of the 4-pyridyl nitrogen atoms and two pyrazine C-H protons on an adjacent complex (Figure ; C(21)-H⋅⋅⋅N(26) = 3.153(5) Å, 133.0(2)°; C(22)-H⋅⋅⋅N(26) = 3.335(5), 116.7(3)°]. The other 4-pyridyl nitrogen is involved in a single nonclassical hydrogen bond [C(37)-H⋅⋅⋅N(6) = 3.149(5) Å, 144.3(3)°]. Together these nonclassical H-bonds result in a 1D chain of complexes (Figure ). The Co⋅⋅⋅Co separation along the chain in polymorph 2 is 8.920 Å whereas it was 8.717 Å in polymorph 1. Interestingly, no pyrazine lone-pair⋅⋅⋅π interactions are observed in polymorph 2 ( Figure S8).

elements.content: The nickel­(II) complex [Ni­(py-pzpypz)2]­(BF4)2·MeCN·CHCl3 is isomorphous with the solvated cobalt­(II) complex (i.e., polymorph 1). Hence both the π–π-stacking interactions and the spare pyrazine nitrogen lone pair to the π-electron poor pyrazine ring on an adjacent complex are observed here too ( Figure S9, Table ). Again, the chloroform molecule hydrogen bonds to one of the tetrafluoroborate anions [Cl3C–H···F = 3.063(3) Å, 153.1(1)°].

Hence both the π-π-stacking interactions and the spare pyrazine nitrogen lone pair to the π-electron poor pyrazine ring on an adjacent complex are observed here too ( Figure S9, Table ). Again, the chloroform molecule hydrogen bonds to one of the tetrafluoroborate anions [Cl3C-H⋅⋅⋅F = 3.063(3) Å, 153.1(1)°].

elements.content: While the manganese­(II) analogue crystallizes solvent-free (in P1̅) and features the most distorted octahedral geometry of all of these complexes (Σ = 160°, Table ), it too exhibits pyrazine π–π-stacking and pyrazine lone-pair−π­(pyrazine) interactions ( Figure S10, Table ). However, the zinc­(II) analogue, [Zn­(py-pzpypz)2]­(BF4)2·2MeCN (Figures and ), shows a different packing arrangement from the “1D chain of complexes” seen for all of the other structures in the P1̅ space group [i.e., for Co­(II) polymorph 1, Mn­(II) and Ni­(II) (Figure and Figures S9 and S10)]. Specifically, in the case of Zn­(II) the pyrazine N(2) lone-pair···π­(pyrazine) interaction is remarkably strong and results in dimeric pairs of interacting molecules (Figures and , Table ). This results in the N4 and N4′ pyrazine rings being too far apart to interact strongly (centroid···centroid 3.474 Å, but the closest contact Y···Z is significantly longer than the other examples, 3.309 Å, Table ).

However, the zinc(II) analogue, [Zn(py-pzpypz)2](BF4)2⋅2MeCN (Figures  and ), shows a different packing arrangement from the "1D chain of complexes" seen for all of the other structures in the P1̅ space group [i.e., for Co(II) polymorph 1, Mn(II) and Ni(II) (Figure  and  Figures S9 and S10)]. Specifically, in the case of Zn(II) the pyrazine N(2) lone-pair⋅⋅⋅π(pyrazine) interaction is remarkably strong and results in dimeric pairs of interacting molecules (Figures  and , Table ). This results in the N4 and N4' pyrazine rings being too far apart to interact strongly (centroid⋅⋅⋅centroid 3.474 Å, but the closest contact Y⋅⋅⋅Z is significantly longer than the other examples, 3.309 Å, Table ).

elements.content:
One of the MeCN molecules and both tetrafluoroborate anions are involved in nonclassical C–H···A hydrogen bonds to the main residue ( Figure S11).

Single crystals of the iron­(II) analogue, [Fe­(py-pzpypz)2]­(BF4)2·solvents, were also grown from vapor diffusion of Et2O into an MeCN solution, of [Fe­(py-pzpypz)2]­(BF4)2·2H2O. These crystals diffracted only weakly, and hence, the quality of data obtained was relatively poor. As a result the crystal packing is not discussed in detail here, but it is isostructural with [Zn­(py-pzpypz)2]­(BF4)2·2MeCN, and hence shows the same packing, albeit without the strong NPz–π interactions.

elements.content: The copper­(II) center adopts a N4O2 octahedral coordination environment binding to one tridentate pocket and the 4-pyridyl nitrogen of an adjacent complex, as well as two DMF molecules axially. As is normal for Cu­(II), the two axial bonds are significantly longer, Co–O21 2.321 Å, than the bonds in the square plane (Cu–N = 1.940–2.078, Table ). The bridging by the 4-pyridyl group results in a 1D chain of complexes and well-separated copper centers (Cu···Cu 10.897 Å). No significant π-stacking interactions are observed either within or between individual 1D chains. There are weak bifurcated nonclassical C–H···F hydrogen bonds between one C–H proton on each of the pyrazine and central pyridine rings and the noncoordinating anion [C(3)–H···F(32) = 3.434(3) Å, 170.1°; C(6)–H···F(32) = 3.419(3) Å, 161.6°], as well as weak interchain C–H···N interactions between one C–H proton on the 4-pyridyl group and the “spare” pyrazine nitrogen of an adjacent chain [C(10)–H···N(2) = 3.437(3) Å, 154.4°].

No significant π-stacking interactions are observed either within or between individual 1D chains. There are weak bifurcated nonclassical C-H⋅⋅⋅F hydrogen bonds between one C-H proton on each of the pyrazine and central pyridine rings and the noncoordinating anion [C(3)-H⋅⋅⋅F(32) = 3.434(3) Å, 170.1°; C(6)-H⋅⋅⋅F(32) = 3.419(3) Å, 161.6°], as well as weak interchain C-H⋅⋅⋅N interactions between one C-H proton on the 4-pyridyl group and the "spare" pyrazine nitrogen of an adjacent chain [C(10)-H⋅⋅⋅N(2) = 3.437(3) Å, 154.4°].

elements.content: Single crystals of [Cu­(py-pzpypz)­Cl2]·MeCN were picked out from the inhomogeneous mixture obtained from heating [Cu­(H2O)4(NO3)2] and py-pzpypz in MeCN to 140 °C in a Teflon lined stainless steel pressure reaction vessel. Presumably there was a trace of chloride present in the reaction vessel. As noted above, a pure sample of this material was subsequently prepared deliberately ().

Presumably there was a trace of chloride present in the reaction vessel. As noted above, a pure sample of this material was subsequently prepared deliberately ().

elements.content: In this case the complex is mononuclear, not polymeric, but an array of intermolecular interactions produces chains of it (Figure , Figure S12). The copper­(II) center adopts a square pyramidal coordination sphere with one chloride anion almost in the plane of the terdentate py-pzpypz ligand, and the other perpendicular to the square plane (hence axial). As expected, the axial chloride bond is significantly weaker than that of the chloride in the square plane [Cu–Cl(1) = 2.421(1) Å; Cu–Cl(2) = 2.225(1) Å], and the Cu–N bonds in the square plane (1.962–2.060 Å, Table ).

The copper(II) center adopts a square pyramidal coordination sphere with one chloride anion almost in the plane of the terdentate py-pzpypz ligand, and the other perpendicular to the square plane (hence axial). As expected, the axial chloride bond is significantly weaker than that of the chloride in the square plane [Cu-Cl(1) = 2.421(1) Å; Cu-Cl(2) = 2.225(1) Å], and the Cu-N bonds in the square plane (1.962-2.060 Å, Table ).

elements.content: Interestingly, the intermolecular interactions in the crystal lattice of this compound are almost entirely composed of weak C–H hydrogen bonds between adjacent complexes, generating supramolecular chains (Figure , Figure S12). The axial chloride interacts with three aromatic ring C–H protons on two adjacent molecules [C(11)–H···Cl(1) = 3.468(4) Å, 126.3°; C(12)–H···Cl(1) = 3.487(4) Å, 126.8°; C(6′)–H···Cl(1) = 3.504(3) Å, 160.2°] and one acetonitrile solvent molecule [C(21)–H···Cl = 3.461(3) Å, 129.3°]. The acetonitrile molecule also acts as a hydrogen bond acceptor [C(8)–H···N(21) = 3.373(4) Å, 170.0°; C(13)–H···N(21) = 3.425(5) Å, 173.6°]. Also, there is one weak π–π-stacking interaction observed between 4-pyridyl groups on adjacent molecules [centroid–centroid =3.550 Å; shortest contact C(16)–C­(14A) = 3.350 Å, Figure S12].
elements.clean_text: Interestingly, the intermolecular interactions in the crystal lattice of this compound are almost entirely composed of weak C-H hydrogen bonds between adjacent complexes, generating supramolecular chains (Figure ,  Figure S12). The axial chloride interacts with three aromatic ring C-H protons on two adjacent molecules [C(11)-H⋅⋅⋅Cl(1) = 3.468(4) Å, 126.3°; C(12)-H⋅⋅⋅Cl(1) = 3.487(4) Å, 126.8°; C(6')-H⋅⋅⋅Cl(1) = 3.504(3) Å, 160.2°] and one acetonitrile solvent molecule [C(21)-H⋅⋅⋅Cl = 3.461(3) Å, 129.3°]. The acetonitrile molecule also acts as a hydrogen bond acceptor [C(8)-H⋅⋅⋅N(21) = 3.373(4) Å, 170.0°; C(13)-H⋅⋅⋅N(21) = 3.425(5) Å, 173.6°]. Also, there is one weak π-π-stacking interaction observed between 4-pyridyl groups on adjacent molecules [centroid-centroid =3.550 Å; shortest contact C(16)-C(14A) = 3.350 Å,  Figure S12].

elements.content: It is helpful to note at the outset that none of the processes described below are observed in the analogous ZnII complex ( Figure S28) indicating that they are metal-centered (not ligand) oxidations and reductions.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemistry

It is helpful to note at the outset that none of the processes described below are observed in the analogous ZnII complex ( Figure S28) indicating that they are metal-centered (not ligand) oxidations and reductions.

elements.content: The complex [CoII(py-pzpypz)2]­(BF4)2 shows two reversible metal based processes (Figure ). The CoII/III couple is observed at E m = +0.37 V and the CoI/II process at −0.63 V (Table ). Interestingly, these two reversible redox processes are at potentials on either side of, and relatively close to, 0 V. The ΔE values and bulk electrolysis results are consistent with both of these processes being one electron transfers ( Figure S16). The latter studies resulted in clear color changes: from orange to peach on oxidation to CoIII and to pale yellow on reduction to CoI (Figure ). Both of these processes are robust reversible redox events, as cyclic voltammograms show them to be unchanged after bulk electrolysis at +0.7 V, forming the CoIII species ( Figure S17, 0.77 electron equivalents), and after two one electron reductions, first at +0.25 V ( Figure S19, 0.68 electron equivalents) and then at −0.9 V ( Figure S21, 0.79 electron equivalents).

The bulk electrolysis of this solution at +1.65 V resulted in a significant color change from violet FeII to yellow FeIII ( Figure S24) and the transfer of 1.02 electron equivalents.

elements.content: Due to the stronger π-acceptor nature of pyrazine, the substitution of pyrazine for pyridine is expected to stabilize the lower oxidation states and hence move the redox potentials to higher values. Consistent with this, all of the observed processes for these complexes of the new pyrazine ligand py-pzpypz are shifted to considerably more positive potentials than those observed for the previously reported complexes of the analogous all-pyridine ligand, [MII(L5)2]2+ where M = Co and Fe (Table ).

elements.content: Several examples of spin crossover have been reported in CoII complexes of terpyridine-type ligands whereas the analogous FeII complexes are generally low spin. While pyrazine is a poorer σ-donor than pyridine, it is also a stronger π-acceptor so it would generally be expected to better stabilize the low spin state in 3d complexes. However, while Halcrow and co-workers found that replacement of the distal pyridine groups in terpyridine by the stronger π-acceptor pyrazine (L2) resulted in low spin complexes of CoII, replacement of the central pyridine by pyrazine resulted in high spin complexes (L3) (Table ). It is intriguing that the complex with central pyrazine donors, [Co­(L3)2]­(BF4)2, has by far the lowest T 1/2 (<50 K) of this family of ligands (Table ), even far lower than the all pyridine terpyridine complex (L1, T 1/2 = 270 K).
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

Several examples of spin crossover have been reported in CoII complexes of terpyridine-type ligands whereas the analogous FeII complexes are generally low spin. While pyrazine is a poorer σ-donor than pyridine, it is also a stronger π-acceptor so it would generally be expected to better stabilize the low spin state in 3d complexes. However, while Halcrow and co-workers found that replacement of the distal pyridine groups in terpyridine by the stronger π-acceptor pyrazine (L2) resulted in low spin complexes of CoII, replacement of the central pyridine by pyrazine resulted in high spin complexes (L3) (Table ). It is intriguing that the complex with central pyrazine donors, [Co(L3)2](BF4)2, has by far the lowest T 1/2 (<50 K) of this family of ligands (Table ), even far lower than the all pyridine terpyridine complex (L1, T 1/2 = 270 K).

elements.content: The effect on cobalt­(II) of replacement of the distal pyridines by pyrazines in terpyridyl-like ligands is further probed here, usig the new py-pzpypz ligand. A potential bonus of the new ligand design is that the “spare” nitrogen donors, in both the pair of pyrazine rings and the 4-pyridyl substituent off the back of the central pyridine ring in py-pzpypz, provide additional hydrogen-bond acceptors which may increase intermolecular interactions and lead to thermal hysteresis, which is only rarely observed for CoII.

elements.content: In contrast, both samples of the cobalt­(II) complex are SCO active, and give similar χm T versus T plots (Figure and Figure S13), despite having substantial differences in crystal packing and solvent content (both factors have been shown to be very important in other cases). Hence, only the air-dried sample of polymorph 1 is described in detail here. The sample of [CoII(py-pzpypz)2]­(BF4)2·2.5­(H2O) obtained on air drying the crystals of polymorph 1 undergoes a gradual spin crossover (Figure ), with χm T decreasing from 1.44 cm3 mol–1 K at 375 K (μeff = 3.40 μB), consistent with approximately 75% HS, to 0.38 cm3 mol–1 K at 4 K (μeff = 1.74 μB), consistent with being fully LS. At 298 K χm T is 1.06 cm3 mol–1 K, ∼50% HS, so the T 1/2 is approximately room temperature for this complex (as the fully HS state could not be achieved, a χm T value of 2.6 cm3 mol–1 K was used to estimate the T 1/2). The gradual nature of this SCO is consistent with that observed in many other Co­(II) terpyridine derivatives.
elements.clean_text: In contrast, both samples of the cobalt(II) complex are SCO active, and give similar χm T versus T plots (Figure  and  Figure S13), despite having substantial differences in crystal packing and solvent content (both factors have been shown to be very important in other cases). Hence, only the air-dried sample of polymorph 1 is described in detail here. The sample of [CoII(py-pzpypz)2](BF4)2⋅2.5(H2O) obtained on air drying the crystals of polymorph 1 undergoes a gradual spin crossover (Figure ), with χm T decreasing from 1.44 cm3 mol-1 K at 375 K (μeff = 3.40 μB), consistent with approximately 75% HS, to 0.38 cm3 mol-1 K at 4 K (μeff = 1.74 μB), consistent with being fully LS. At 298 K χm T is 1.06 cm3 mol-1 K, ~50% HS, so the T 1/2 is approximately room temperature for this complex (as the fully HS state could not be achieved, a χm T value of 2.6 cm3 mol-1 K was used to estimate the T 1/2). The gradual nature of this SCO is consistent with that observed in many other Co(II) terpyridine derivatives.

elements.content: The presence of the distal pyrazine nitrogen donors in py-pzpypz has stabilized the LS state only slightly, as T 1/2 only increased by ∼30 K when compared to the analogous all pyridine donor terpyridine complex, [Co­(L1)2]­(BF4)2 (T 1/2 = 270 K). Interestingly, the other analogues that feature distal pyrazine donors, [CoII(L2)2]­(BF4)2 and [CoII(L4)]­(BF4)2, remain almost fully LS up to 300 K (Table ), so py-pzpypz is not as effective at stabilizing the LS state as those ligands are. This may well be due in part to differences in packing interactions due to the presence of the 4-pyridyl moiety “out the back” of py-pzpypz.

Interestingly, the other analogues that feature distal pyrazine donors, [CoII(L2)2](BF4)2 and [CoII(L4)](BF4)2, remain almost fully LS up to 300 K (Table ), so py-pzpypz is not as effective at stabilizing the LS state as those ligands are. This may well be due in part to differences in packing interactions due to the presence of the 4-pyridyl moiety "out the back" of py-pzpypz.

elements.content: Interestingly, the fine balance of the ligand field provided to cobalt­(II) by two py-pzpypz ligands has led to the SCO event being centered close to ambient temperature. However, despite the intermolecular interactions achieved by through the noncoordinating nitrogen atoms (Figures and ), the SCO shows the gradual nature that is characteristic of many CoII terpyridine-type complexes.

The synthesis and structural characterization of a new ligand 4-(4-pyridyl)-2,5-dipyrazyl-pyridine (py-pzpypz) and seven first row transition metal complexes of it are reported, along with magnetic and electrochemical characterization of the complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The synthesis and structural characterization of a new ligand 4-(4-pyridyl)-2,5-dipyrazyl-pyridine (py-pzpypz) and seven first row transition metal complexes of it are reported, along with magnetic and electrochemical characterization of the complexes.

elements.content: In all of the complexes investigated, except for copper­(II), a 2:1 L:M reaction stoichiometry leads to an [ML2]2+ product, resulting in six “spare” N donors pointing out approximately along the axes of an octahedron. This results in a range of interesting crystal packing interactions, most notably lone-pair···π­(pyrazine) interactions. These “spare” N donors also endow the complexes with the potential to be used as secondary building units (SBUs) for subsequent assembly into supramolecular architectures as we have recently demonstrated with imide complexes.
elements.clean_text: In all of the complexes investigated, except for copper(II), a 2:1 L:M reaction stoichiometry leads to an [ML2]2+ product, resulting in six "spare" N donors pointing out approximately along the axes of an octahedron. This results in a range of interesting crystal packing interactions, most notably lone-pair⋅⋅⋅π(pyrazine) interactions. These "spare" N donors also endow the complexes with the potential to be used as secondary building units (SBUs) for subsequent assembly into supramolecular architectures as we have recently demonstrated with imide complexes.

elements.content: In the case of copper­(II), despite a 2:1 L:M reaction, the products obtained were 1:1. With tetrafluoroborate counterions the product is a 1D chain polymer, featuring bridging of the N4O2 octahedral copper­(II) centers by the 4-pyridyl donors “out the back”, whereas with chloride counterions discrete [CuLCl2] complexes of square pyramidal copper­(II) centers are obtained.

elements.content: The [FeII(py-pzpypz)2]­(BF4)2 complex is low spin whereas a gradual spin crossover, over the range 50–375 K, is observed for [CoII(py-pzpypz)2]­(BF4)2. A quasireversible FeII/III process is observed in the iron­(II) complex. Two reversible one electron redox processes, attributed to the CoI/II and CoII/III, are observed in the cobalt­(II) complex. The potentials at which these occur are about 450 mV higher than those observed in the corresponding complexes of the analogous all-pyridine ligand, consistent with the replacement of two pyridine rings by pyrazine rings significantly stabilizing the lower oxidation states.

The potentials at which these occur are about 450 mV higher than those observed in the corresponding complexes of the analogous all-pyridine ligand, consistent with the replacement of two pyridine rings by pyrazine rings significantly stabilizing the lower oxidation states.

Experimental Section

Except where noted, all chemicals, including pyrazine and pyridine-4-carbaldehyde, were of reagent grade and used as received without further purification. 2-Acetylpyrazine was prepared from pyrazine according to the published procedure. Methanol and acetonitrile were HPLC grade.

elements.content: A pale yellow solution of 2-acetylpyrazine (600 mg, 4.91 mmol) and pyridine-4-carbaldehyde (267 mg, 2.49 mmol) in MeOH (8 mL) was prepared by stirring at room temperature (RT) for 5 min. To this solution was added a solution of KOH (2.13 g, 38 mmol) in H2O (14.4 mL) and saturated aqueous ammonia solution (1.6 mL). The solution turned dark red, and a precipitate began to form almost immediately. The reaction vessel was loosely stoppered and stirred at RT for 24 h. Then H2O (8 mL) was added and the suspension extracted with CHCl3 (6 × 70 mL), and the combined organic extracts were dried over Na2SO4 and filtered to give a clear pale yellow solution. Removal of the solvent at reduced pressure gave the crude product as a pale yellow solid. This was suspended in acetone (20 mL), sonicated for 5 min, filtered, washed with acetone (3 × 10 mL), and dried in vacuo to give 4-(4-pyridyl)-2,6-di­(2-pyrazinyl)­pyridine (py-pzpypz) as a white powder (456 mg, 1.46 mmol, 58.6%). Anal. Calcd (%) for C18H12N6 (312.33): C 69.22, H 3.87, N 26.91. Found: C 69.42, H 3.87, N 26.83. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 9.89 (2H, d, JH3–H2 = 1.4 Hz, 2 × H3), 8.80 (2H, JH10–H9A = 4.4 Hz, JH10–H9B = 1.7 Hz, 2 × H10), 8.77 (2H, s, 2 × H6), 8.70 (4H, m, 2 × H1, 2 × H2), 7.78 (2H, JH9–H10A = 4.4 Hz, JH9–H10B = 1.7 Hz, 2 × H9). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 119.7 (C6), 121.5 (C9), 143.6 (C3), 143.6 (C1/C2), 145.1 (C1/C2), 145.3 (C8), 148.1 (C7), 150.3 (C5), 150.8 (C10), 154.9 (C4). HR-ESI-MS (pos) m/z = 335.1044, calcd for [C18H12N6Na]+ = 335.1016. ATR-IR (ν/cm–1): 3075­(w), 1594­(m), 1533­(w), 1503­(w) 1432­(w), 1375­(m), 1325­(w), 1247­(w), 1127­(w), 1112­(m), 1034­(m), 1019(s), 856­(m), 813(s), 687­(m), 813(s), 687­(m), 621(s), 579­(m), 473­(m), 398(s). Colorless block shaped single crystals of py-pzpypz·HCl·H2O, suitable for X-ray crystallography, were grown by vapor diffusion of HCl (from a dilute aqueous HCl solution) into a CHCl3 solution of py-pzpypz.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 4-(4-Pyridyl)-2,6-di(2-pyrazinyl)pyridine (py-pzpypz)

A pale yellow solution of 2-acetylpyrazine (600 mg, 4.91 mmol) and pyridine-4-carbaldehyde (267 mg, 2.49 mmol) in MeOH (8 mL) was prepared by stirring at room temperature (RT) for 5 min. To this solution was added a solution of KOH (2.13 g, 38 mmol) in H2O (14.4 mL) and saturated aqueous ammonia solution (1.6 mL). The solution turned dark red, and a precipitate began to form almost immediately. The reaction vessel was loosely stoppered and stirred at RT for 24 h. Then H2O (8 mL) was added and the suspension extracted with CHCl3 (6 × 70 mL), and the combined organic extracts were dried over Na2SO4 and filtered to give a clear pale yellow solution. Removal of the solvent at reduced pressure gave the crude product as a pale yellow solid. This was suspended in acetone (20 mL), sonicated for 5 min, filtered, washed with acetone (3 × 10 mL), and dried in vacuo to give 4-(4-pyridyl)-2,6-di(2-pyrazinyl)pyridine (py-pzpypz) as a white powder (456 mg, 1.46 mmol, 58.6%). Anal.  Calcd (%) for C18H12N6 (312.33): C 69.22, H 3.87, N 26.91. Found: C 69.42, H 3.87, N 26.83. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 9.89 (2H, d, JH3-H2 = 1.4 Hz, 2 × H3), 8.80 (2H, JH10-H9A = 4.4 Hz, JH10-H9B = 1.7 Hz, 2 × H10), 8.77 (2H, s, 2 × H6), 8.70 (4H, m, 2 × H1, 2 × H2), 7.78 (2H, JH9-H10A = 4.4 Hz, JH9-H10B = 1.7 Hz, 2 × H9). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 119.7 (C6), 121.5 (C9), 143.6 (C3), 143.6 (C1/C2), 145.1 (C1/C2), 145.3 (C8), 148.1 (C7), 150.3 (C5), 150.8 (C10), 154.9 (C4). HR-ESI-MS (pos) m/z = 335.1044, calcd for [C18H12N6Na]+ = 335.1016. ATR-IR (ν/cm-1): 3075(w), 1594(m), 1533(w), 1503(w) 1432(w), 1375(m), 1325(w), 1247(w), 1127(w), 1112(m), 1034(m), 1019(s), 856(m), 813(s), 687(m), 813(s), 687(m), 621(s), 579(m), 473(m), 398(s). Colorless block shaped single crystals of py-pzpypz⋅HCl⋅H2O, suitable for X-ray crystallography, were grown by vapor diffusion of HCl (from a dilute aqueous HCl solution) into a CHCl3 solution of py-pzpypz.

elements.content: A colorless solution of py-pzpypz (50.5 mg, 16.2 mmol) in a mixture of MeOH and CHCl3 (1:1, 60 mL) was bubbled with N2(g) for 10 min. A pale blue solution of [Fe­(H2O)6]­(BF4)2 (26.6 mg, 0.079 mmol) in MeOH (2 mL) was also bubbled with N2(g) for 5 min before being added to the first solution, resulting in the immediate formation of a dark purple precipitate. A nitrogen balloon was attached, the N2 flow stopped, and the vessel stirred at RT for 2 h. The dark purple powder was filtered, dried under a flow of N2(g), and then further dried under vacuum (34.1 mg, 47.7%). Anal. Calcd (%) for [Fe­(py-pzpypz)2]­(BF4)2·2H2O (C36H28N12­O2FeB2F8, 890.15 g mol–1): C 48.58, H 3.17, N 18.88. Found: C 48.96, H 3.11, N 18.59. HR-ESI-MS (pos) m/z = 340.0791, calcd for [C36H24N12Fe]2+ = 340.0793. elements.clean_text:
[Fe(py-pzpypz)2](BF4)2⋅2H2O

A colorless solution of py-pzpypz (50.5 mg, 16.2 mmol) in a mixture of MeOH and CHCl3 (1:1, 60 mL) was bubbled with N2(g) for 10 min. A pale blue solution of [Fe(H2O)6](BF4)2 (26.6 mg, 0.079 mmol) in MeOH (2 mL) was also bubbled with N2(g) for 5 min before being added to the first solution, resulting in the immediate formation of a dark purple precipitate. A nitrogen balloon was attached, the N2 flow stopped, and the vessel stirred at RT for 2 h. The dark purple powder was filtered, dried under a flow of N2(g), and then further dried under vacuum (34.1 mg, 47.7%). Anal. Calcd (%) for [Fe(py-pzpypz)2](BF4)2⋅2H2O (C36H28N12O2FeB2F8, 890.15 g mol-1): C 48.58, H 3.17, N 18.88. Found: C 48.96, H 3.11, N 18.59. HR-ESI-MS (pos) m/z = 340.0791, calcd for [C36H24N12Fe]2+ = 340.0793. ATR-IR (ν/cm-1): 3618(w), 3078(w), 1599(m), 1485(w), 1428(w), 1405(m), 1356(w), 1295(w), 1195(m), 1055(s, br), 824(s, sh), 647(w), 636(w), 522(w), 499(m), 465(m). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3CN): δ (ppm) 9.71 (4H, d, JH3-H2 = 1.1 Hz, 4 × H3), 9.37 (4H, s, 4 × H6), 9.08 (4H, dd, JH10-H9A = 4.4 Hz, JH10-H9B = 1.7 Hz, 4 × H10), 8.31 (4H, d, JH1-H2 = 3.2 Hz, 4 × H1), 8.24 (4H, dd, JH9-H10A = 4.4 Hz, JH9-H10B = 1.7 Hz, 4 × H9), 7.32 (4H, dd, JH2-H1 = 3.2 Hz, JH2-H3 = 1.1 Hz, 4 × H2). TGA, Δmass found 4.2%, calcd for 2H2O 4.1%. Violet, needle shaped, crystals of [Fe(py-pzpypz)2](BF4)2⋅(solvents) suitable for X-ray crystallography were obtained by Et2O vapor diffusion into an MeCN solution of [Fe(py-pzpypz)2](BF4)2⋅2H2O.

To a colorless solution of py-pzpypz (200 mg, 0.64 mmol) in a mixture of MeOH (75 mL) and CHCl3 (125 mL) was added [Co­(H2O)6]­(BF4)2 (109 mg, 0.32 mmol) in MeOH (25 mL) resulting in the immediate formation of a brick red precipitate. The suspension was stirred at ambient temperature for 2 h and then filtered and washed with CHCl3/MeOH (1:1, 2 × 2 mL). The resulting red solid was air-dried and then further dried under vacuum (241 mg, 0.26 mmol, 81%). Anal. Calcd (%) for [Co­(py-pzpypz)2]­(BF4)2·2.5H2O (C36H29N12­O2.5CoB2F8, 902.24 g mol–1): C 47.92, H 3.24, N 18.63. Found: C 47.99, H 2.88, N 18.43. HR-ESI-MS (pos) m/z = 341.5772, calcd for [C36H24N12Co]2+ = 341.5784. ATR-IR (ν/cm–1): 3607­(w, br), 3086­(w), 1620­(w), 1599­(m), 1473­(w), 1403(s), 1190­(w), 1035­(s, br), 823(s), 482­(m), 418­(m). TGA, Δmass found 5.2%, calcd for 2.5H2O 5.0%. Red needle shaped crystals of the solvent-free polymorph 2 suitable for X-ray crystallography were obtained by Et2O vapor diffusion into an MeCN solution of [Co­(py-pzpypz)2]­(BF4)2. Red block shaped crystals of [Co­(py-pzpypz)2]­(BF4)2·MeCN·CHCl3 (polymorph 1) suitable for X-ray crystallography were grown by vapor diffusion of CHCl3 into an MeCN solution of [Co­(py-pzpypz)2]­(BF4)2. After air drying the crystals of polymorph 1, the sample analyzed as [Co­(py-pzpypz)2]­(BF4)2·2.5H2O. Anal. Calcd (%) for C36H29N12O2.5CoB2F8 (902.24): C 47.97, H 2.88, N 18.63. Found: C 47.80, H 3.14, N 18.33.

elements.content: To a white suspension of py-pzpypz (38.8 mg, 0.124 mmol) in 60 mL of MeCN at reflux was added a blue solution of [Ni­(H2O)6]­(BF4)2 (21 mg, 0.064 mmol) in 10 mL of MeCN. After approximately 10 min the yellow suspension cleared to give a golden solution which was refluxed for 22 h. This solution was reduced in volume to 30 mL by rotary evaporation and then subjected to CHCl3 vapor diffusion, resulting in formation of golden-yellow block shaped crystals of [Ni­(py-pzpypz)2]­(BF4)2·MeCN·CHCl3 suitable for X-ray crystallography. The crystals were filtered, air-dried, and then further dried under vacuum (43.0 mg, 0.042 mmol, 67%). The solvent molecules are replaced by H2O on exposure to air. Anal. Calcd for [Ni­(py-pzpypz)2]­(BF4)2·2H2O (C36H28N12B2F8O2Ni, 892.99 g mol–1) (%): C 48.42, H 3.16, N 18.82. Found: C 48.58, H 2.97, 18.91. Caution! While no problems were encountered in the course of this work perchlorate mixtures are potentially explosive and should therefore be handled with appropriate care.

A white suspension of py-pzpypz (60.4 mg, 0.19 mmol) in MeCN (30 mL) at reflux was bubbled with Ar­(g) for 5 min before [Mn­(H2O)6]­(ClO4)2 (35.9 mg, 99 μmol) in MeCN (2 mL) was added. Upon addition of the metal salt the suspension immediately cleared to give a yellow solution. Ar­(g) bubbling was continued for a further 2 min before an Ar balloon was attached, the Ar flow stopped, and the solution refluxed for 1 h. The solution was allowed to cool to RT and then subjected to vapor diffusion of iPr2O, resulting in yellow block shaped crystals of [MnII(py-pzpypz)2]­(ClO4)2·2MeCN suitable for X-ray crystallography after 2 days. These were filtered and washed with Et2O/DCM (1:1, 3 × 15 mL), then air-dried to give [Mn­(py-pzpypz)2]­(ClO4)2 1.5H2O as a yellow powder (the crystals collapse on drying as lattice MeCN is replaced by H2O (43 mg, 49 μmol, 49.4%). Anal. Calcd for [Mn­(py-pzpypz)2]­(ClO4)2·1.5H2O (C36H27N12­B2F8O1.5Mn, 881.24 g mol–1) (%): C 49.07, H 3.20, N 19.07. Found: C 49.27, H 3.26, N 18.98. HR-ESI-MS (pos) m/z = 339.5807, calcd for [C36H24N12Mn]2+ = 339.5808; m/z = 778.1070, calcd for [C36H24N12MnClO4]+ = 778.1100. ATR-IR (ν/cm–1) = 3078­(w, br), 2918­(w), 2850­(w), 1617­(m), 1477­(m), 1402­(m), 1172­(m), 1080­(vs), 1032­(s, sh), 854­(m), 821­(m, sh), 619­(s, sh), 478­(m, sh), 409­(s, sh). TGA was not carried out on this material due to the potential explosion risk of perchlorate salts when heated.

elements.content: A green suspension of py-pzpypz (50 mg, 0.16 mmol) and copper tetrafluoroborate hydrate (56.5 mg, 0.16 mmol) in DMF (12 mL) was stirred at RT for 75 min. The resulting green solution was subjected to vapor diffusion of Et2O, and green microcrystalline solid was obtained after 1 week. The solid was filtered and then dissolved in DMF (25 mL) and subjected to Et2O vapor diffusion. After 2 weeks the resulting green block shaped crystals of {[Cu­(py-pzpypz)­(DMF)2]­(BF4)2·DMF} n , suitable for X-ray crystallography, were obtained. These crystals were filtered and washed with DCM (2 × 20 mL) and Et2O (20 mL) and then air-dried. The crystals collapse to a green powder on drying. Further drying in vacuo followed by exposure to air resulted in substitution of the two coordinated DMF molecules for H2O (51.0 mg, 0.073 mmol, 46%). Anal. Calcd (%) for {[Cu­(py-pzpypz)­(H2O)2]­(BF4)2} n (C18H16N6­O2B2F8Cu, 585.52 g mol–1): C 37.10, H 2.49, N 14.71. Found: C 36.92, H 2.75, N 14.35. ATR-IR (ν/cm–1) = 3101­(w), 1617­(m, sh), 1404­(m), 1066­(vs), 1040­(vs, br), 846­(m, sh), 676 (m), 517­(m, sh), 494­(s, sh), 421­(s, sh).

elements.content: A sample tube was loaded with a solution of py-pzpypz (30 mg, 0.096 mmol) in DCM/MeOH (4:1, 20 mL). On this was layered a buffer of DCM/MeOH (1:1, 6 mL) and then a layer of CuCl2 (16.4 mg, 0.096 mmol) in MeOH (3 mL). The tube was sealed, and the solutions were allowed to slowly diffuse together, which resulted in green microcrystals after 48 h. These were filtered and washed with MeOH (3 × 5 mL) and DCM (3 × 10 mL), then air-dried (32 mg, 0.072 mmol, 75%). Anal. Calcd (%) for [Cu­(py-pzpypz)­Cl2]·DCM (C19H14­N6Cl4Cu, 446.85 g mol–1): C 42.92, H 2.65, N 15.81. Found: C 42.17, H 2.75, N 15.85. HR-ESI-MS (pos) m/z = 410.0068; calcd for [Cu­(C18H12N6)­Cl]+ = 410.0102. ATR-IR (ν/cm–1) = 3019 (m), 1598 (m, sh), 1472 (w, sh), 1457 (m), 1404 (m), 1395­(m), 1176­(m), 1151­(m, sh), 1039­(s, sh), 831.31(s), 627­(w), 463(s), 410(s). A single crystal sample of [Cu­(py-pzpypz)­Cl2]·MeCN was obtained serendipitously: To a Teflon-lined stainless steel reaction vessel was added [Cu­(H2O)4(NO3)2] (11.6 mg, 45 μmol), py-pzpypz (14.0 mg 45 μmol), and MeCN (15 mL). The pressure vessel was sealed and heated at 140 °C for 72 h and then allowed to slowly cool to RT, resulting in an inhomogeneous mixture, including a few green plate shaped single crystals which were suitable for X-ray crystallography.

cln_elements.content:
Analytically pure powder samples of three of the [MII(py-pzpypz)2]­(X)2 complexes, where M = Fe, Co, Zn and X = BF4, were precipitated immediately on adding a MeOH solution of MII(BF4)2 to a MeOH/CHCl3 solution of py-pzpypz, due to the low solubility of the complexes in this solvent mixture. This method could also be used to prepare the yellow MnII (X = ClO4) complex; however, better yields (50%) were obtained using the refluxing MeCN strategy adopted for NiII (see next paragraph). These FeII (dark purple), CoII (red), and ZnII (white) complexes are obtained in 48–81% yields. They are insoluble in most common solvents (H2O, MeOH, CHCl3, DCM), with the notable exception of MeCN.

Synthesis of 4-(4-Pyridyl)-2,6-di­(2-pyrazinyl)­pyridine (py-pzpypz)

A pale yellow solution of 2-acetylpyrazine (600 mg, 4.91 mmol) and pyridine-4-carbaldehyde (267 mg, 2.49 mmol) in MeOH (8 mL) was prepared by stirring at room temperature (RT) for 5 min. To this solution was added a solution of KOH (2.13 g, 38 mmol) in H2O (14.4 mL) and saturated aqueous ammonia solution (1.6 mL). The solution turned dark red, and a precipitate began to form almost immediately. The reaction vessel was loosely stoppered and stirred at RT for 24 h. Then H2O (8 mL) was added and the suspension extracted with CHCl3 (6 × 70 mL), and the combined organic extracts were dried over Na2SO4 and filtered to give a clear pale yellow solution. Removal of the solvent at reduced pressure gave the crude product as a pale yellow solid. This was suspended in acetone (20 mL), sonicated for 5 min, filtered, washed with acetone (3 × 10 mL), and dried in vacuo to give 4-(4-pyridyl)-2,6-di­(2-pyrazinyl)­pyridine (py-pzpypz) as a white powder (456 mg, 1.46 mmol, 58.6%). Anal. Calcd (%) for C18H12N6 (312.33): C 69.22, H 3.87, N 26.91. Found: C 69.42, H 3.87, N 26.83. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 9.89 (2H, d, JH3–H2 = 1.4 Hz, 2 × H3), 8.80 (2H, JH10–H9A = 4.4 Hz, JH10–H9B = 1.7 Hz, 2 × H10), 8.77 (2H, s, 2 × H6), 8.70 (4H, m, 2 × H1, 2 × H2), 7.78 (2H, JH9–H10A = 4.4 Hz, JH9–H10B = 1.7 Hz, 2 × H9). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 119.7 (C6), 121.5 (C9), 143.6 (C3), 143.6 (C1/C2), 145.1 (C1/C2), 145.3 (C8), 148.1 (C7), 150.3 (C5), 150.8 (C10), 154.9 (C4). HR-ESI-MS (pos) m/z = 335.1044, calcd for [C18H12N6Na]+ = 335.1016. ATR-IR (ν/cm–1): 3075­(w), 1594­(m), 1533­(w), 1503­(w) 1432­(w), 1375­(m), 1325­(w), 1247­(w), 1127­(w), 1112­(m), 1034­(m), 1019(s), 856­(m), 813(s), 687­(m), 813(s), 687­(m), 621(s), 579­(m), 473­(m), 398(s). Colorless block shaped single crystals of py-pzpypz·HCl·H2O, suitable for X-ray crystallography, were grown by vapor diffusion of HCl (from a dilute aqueous HCl solution) into a CHCl3 solution of py-pzpypz.

{[Cu­(py-pzpypz)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]­(BF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub>

A green suspension of py-pzpypz (50 mg, 0.16 mmol) and copper tetrafluoroborate hydrate (56.5 mg, 0.16 mmol) in DMF (12 mL) was stirred at RT for 75 min. The resulting green solution was subjected to vapor diffusion of Et2O, and green microcrystalline solid was obtained after 1 week. The solid was filtered and then dissolved in DMF (25 mL) and subjected to Et2O vapor diffusion. After 2 weeks the resulting green block shaped crystals of {[Cu­(py-pzpypz)­(DMF)2]­(BF4)2·DMF} n , suitable for X-ray crystallography, were obtained. These crystals were filtered and washed with DCM (2 × 20 mL) and Et2O (20 mL) and then air-dried. The crystals collapse to a green powder on drying. Further drying in vacuo followed by exposure to air resulted in substitution of the two coordinated DMF molecules for H2O (51.0 mg, 0.073 mmol, 46%). Anal. Calcd (%) for {[Cu­(py-pzpypz)­(H2O)2]­(BF4)2} n (C18H16N6­O2B2F8Cu, 585.52 g mol–1): C 37.10, H 2.49, N 14.71. Found: C 36.92, H 2.75, N 14.35. [Cu­(py-pzpypz)­Cl<sub>2</sub>]·DCM

A sample tube was loaded with a solution of py-pzpypz (30 mg, 0.096 mmol) in DCM/MeOH (4:1, 20 mL). On this was layered a buffer of DCM/MeOH (1:1, 6 mL) and then a layer of CuCl2 (16.4 mg, 0.096 mmol) in MeOH (3 mL). The tube was sealed, and the solutions were allowed to slowly diffuse together, which resulted in green microcrystals after 48 h. These were filtered and washed with MeOH (3 × 5 mL) and DCM (3 × 10 mL), then air-dried (32 mg, 0.072 mmol, 75%). Anal. Calcd (%) for [Cu­(py-pzpypz)­Cl2]·DCM (C19H14­N6Cl4Cu, 446.85 g mol–1): C 42.92, H 2.65, N 15.81. Found: C 42.17, H 2.75, N 15.85. HR-ESI-MS (pos) m/z = 410.0068; calcd for [Cu­(C18H12N6)­Cl]+ = 410.0102. ATR-IR (ν/cm–1) = 3019 (m), 1598 (m, sh), 1472 (w, sh), 1457 (m), 1404 (m), 1395­(m), 1176­(m), 1151­(m, sh), 1039­(s, sh), 831.31(s), 627­(w), 463(s), 410(s). A single crystal sample of [Cu­(py-pzpypz)­Cl2]·MeCN was obtained serendipitously: To a Teflon-lined stainless steel reaction vessel was added [Cu­(H2O)4(NO3)2] (11.6 mg, 45 μmol), py-pzpypz (14.0 mg 45 μmol), and MeCN (15 mL). The pressure vessel was sealed and heated at 140 °C for 72 h and then allowed to slowly cool to RT, resulting in an inhomogeneous mixture, including a few green plate shaped single crystals which were suitable for X-ray crystallography.

Synthesis of [MII(py-pzpypz)](X)2 

Analytically pure powder samples of three of the [MII(py-pzpypz)2](X)2 complexes, where M = Fe, Co, Zn and X = BF4, were precipitated immediately on adding a MeOH solution of MII(BF4)2 to a MeOH/CHCl3 solution of py-pzpypz, due to the low solubility of the complexes in this solvent mixture. This method could also be used to prepare the yellow MnII (X = ClO4) complex; however, better yields (50%) were obtained using the refluxing MeCN strategy adopted for NiII (see next paragraph). These FeII (dark purple), CoII (red), and ZnII (white) complexes are obtained in 48-81% yields. They are insoluble in most common solvents (H2O, MeOH, CHCl3, DCM), with the notable exception of MeCN.

Synthesis of 4-(4-Pyridyl)-2,6-di(2-pyrazinyl)pyridine (py-pzpypz)

A pale yellow solution of 2-acetylpyrazine (600 mg, 4.91 mmol) and pyridine-4-carbaldehyde (267 mg, 2.49 mmol) in MeOH (8 mL) was prepared by stirring at room temperature (RT) for 5 min. To this solution was added a solution of KOH (2.13 g, 38 mmol) in H2O (14.4 mL) and saturated aqueous ammonia solution (1.6 mL). The solution turned dark red, and a precipitate began to form almost immediately. The reaction vessel was loosely stoppered and stirred at RT for 24 h. Then H2O (8 mL) was added and the suspension extracted with CHCl3 (6 × 70 mL), and the combined organic extracts were dried over Na2SO4 and filtered to give a clear pale yellow solution. Removal of the solvent at reduced pressure gave the crude product as a pale yellow solid. This was suspended in acetone (20 mL), sonicated for 5 min, filtered, washed with acetone (3 × 10 mL), and dried in vacuo to give 4-(4-pyridyl)-2,6-di(2-pyrazinyl)pyridine (py-pzpypz) as a white powder (456 mg, 1.46 mmol, 58.6%). Anal.  Calcd (%) for C18H12N6 (312.33): C 69.22, H 3.87, N 26.91. Found: C 69.42, H 3.87, N 26.83. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 9.89 (2H, d, JH3-H2 = 1.4 Hz, 2 × H3), 8.80 (2H, JH10-H9A = 4.4 Hz, JH10-H9B = 1.7 Hz, 2 × H10), 8.77 (2H, s, 2 × H6), 8.70 (4H, m, 2 × H1, 2 × H2), 7.78 (2H, JH9-H10A = 4.4 Hz, JH9-H10B = 1.7 Hz, 2 × H9). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 119.7 (C6), 121.5 (C9), 143.6 (C3), 143.6 (C1/C2), 145.1 (C1/C2), 145.3 (C8), 148.1 (C7), 150.3 (C5), 150.8 (C10), 154.9 (C4). HR-ESI-MS (pos) m/z = 335.1044, calcd for [C18H12N6Na]+ = 335.1016. ATR-IR (ν/cm-1): 3075(w), 1594(m), 1533(w), 1503(w) 1432(w), 1375(m), 1325(w), 1247(w), 1127(w), 1112(m), 1034(m), 1019(s), 856(m), 813(s), 687(m), 813(s), 687(m), 621(s), 579(m), 473(m), 398(s). Colorless block shaped single crystals of py-pzpypz⋅HCl⋅H2O, suitable for X-ray crystallography, were grown by vapor diffusion of HCl (from a dilute aqueous HCl solution) into a CHCl3 solution of py-pzpypz.

[Zn(py-pzpypz)2](BF4)2⋅1.5H2O

To a colorless solution of py-pzpypz (40 mg, 128 μmol) in a mixture of MeOH and CHCl3 (1:1, 50 mL) was added [Zn(H2O)6](BF4)2 (22 mg, 64 μmol) in MeOH (2 mL) resulting in the immediate formation of a white precipitate. The suspension was stirred at RT for 2 h, then filtered, and the solid washed with CHCl3 (2 mL) and MeOH (2 mL). The resulting white solid was air-dried and then further dried under vacuum (31 mg, 35 μmol, 54%). Anal. Calcd (%) for [Zn(py-pzpypz)2](BF4)2⋅1.5H2O (C37H27N12O1.5FeB2F8, 890.68 g mol-1): C 48.55, H 3.06, N 18.87. Found: C 48.47, H 2.91, N 18.60. HR-ESI-MS (pos) m/z = 344.0735, calcd for [C36H24N12Zn]2+ = 344.0764. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3CN): δ (ppm) 10.0 (4H, d, JH3-H2 = 1.4 Hz, 4 × H3), 9.22 (4H, s, 4 × H6), 9.04 (4H, dd, JH10-H9A = 4.4 Hz, JH10-H9B = 1.7 Hz, 4 × H10), 8.77 (4H, d, JH1-H2 = 2.6 Hz, 4 × H1), 8.15 (4H, dd, JH9-H10A = 4.4 Hz, JH9-H10B = 1.7 Hz, 4 × H9), 7.86 (4H, dd, JH2-H1 = 2.6 Hz, JH2-H3 = 1.4 Hz, 4 × H2). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CD3CN): δ (ppm) 154.51, 151.28, 149.34, 148.76, 145.35, 142.84, 142.35, 141.76, 123.26, 122.07. ATR-IR (ν/cm-1) = 3100 (w), 1619 (w), 1600 (m, sh), 1478(w), 1402(m), 1150(w), 1034(vs, br), 823(s, sh), 623(w, sh), 471(m), 415(s, sh). TGA, Δmass found 2.9%, calcd for 1.5H2O 3.1%. Colorless block shaped crystals of [Zn(py-pzpypz)2](BF4)2⋅2MeCN were grown by vapor diffusion of Et2O into an MeCN solution of the white solid.

{[Cu(py-pzpypz)(H2O)2](BF4)2} n  

A green suspension of py-pzpypz (50 mg, 0.16 mmol) and copper tetrafluoroborate hydrate (56.5 mg, 0.16 mmol) in DMF (12 mL) was stirred at RT for 75 min. The resulting green solution was subjected to vapor diffusion of Et2O, and green microcrystalline solid was obtained after 1 week. The solid was filtered and then dissolved in DMF (25 mL) and subjected to Et2O vapor diffusion. After 2 weeks the resulting green block shaped crystals of {[Cu(py-pzpypz)(DMF)2](BF4)2⋅DMF} n , suitable for X-ray crystallography, were obtained. These crystals were filtered and washed with DCM (2 × 20 mL) and Et2O (20 mL) and then air-dried. The crystals collapse to a green powder on drying. Further drying in vacuo followed by exposure to air resulted in substitution of the two coordinated DMF molecules for H2O (51.0 mg, 0.073 mmol, 46%). Anal. Calcd (%) for {[Cu(py-pzpypz)(H2O)2](BF4)2} n  (C18H16N6O2B2F8Cu, 585.52 g mol-1): C 37.10, H 2.49, N 14.71. Found: C 36.92, H 2.75, N 14.35. ATR-IR (ν/cm-1) = 3101(w), 1617(m, sh), 1404(m), 1066(vs), 1040(vs, br), 846(m, sh), 676 (m), 517(m, sh), 494(s, sh), 421(s, sh).

[Cu(py-pzpypz)Cl2]⋅DCM

A sample tube was loaded with a solution of py-pzpypz (30 mg, 0.096 mmol) in DCM/MeOH (4:1, 20 mL). On this was layered a buffer of DCM/MeOH (1:1, 6 mL) and then a layer of CuCl2 (16.4 mg, 0.096 mmol) in MeOH (3 mL). The tube was sealed, and the solutions were allowed to slowly diffuse together, which resulted in green microcrystals after 48 h. These were filtered and washed with MeOH (3 × 5 mL) and DCM (3 × 10 mL), then air-dried (32 mg, 0.072 mmol, 75%). Anal. Calcd (%) for [Cu(py-pzpypz)Cl2]⋅DCM (C19H14N6Cl4Cu, 446.85 g mol-1): C 42.92, H 2.65, N 15.81. Found: C 42.17, H 2.75, N 15.85. HR-ESI-MS (pos) m/z = 410.0068; calcd for [Cu(C18H12N6)Cl]+ = 410.0102. ATR-IR (ν/cm-1) = 3019 (m), 1598 (m, sh), 1472 (w, sh), 1457 (m), 1404 (m), 1395(m), 1176(m), 1151(m, sh), 1039(s, sh), 831.31(s), 627(w), 463(s), 410(s). A single crystal sample of [Cu(py-pzpypz)Cl2]⋅MeCN was obtained serendipitously: To a Teflon-lined stainless steel reaction vessel was added [Cu(H2O)4(NO3)2] (11.6 mg, 45 μmol), py-pzpypz (14.0 mg 45 μmol), and MeCN (15 mL). The pressure vessel was sealed and heated at 140 °C for 72 h and then allowed to slowly cool to RT, resulting in an inhomogeneous mixture, including a few green plate shaped single crystals which were suitable for X-ray crystallography.

cln_elements.content: In contrast, both samples of the cobalt­(II) complex are SCO active, and give similar χm T versus T plots (Figure and Figure S13), despite having substantial differences in crystal packing and solvent content (both factors have been shown to be very important in other cases). Hence, only the air-dried sample of polymorph 1 is described in detail here. The sample of [CoII(py-pzpypz)2]­(BF4)2·2.5­(H2O) obtained on air drying the crystals of polymorph 1 undergoes a gradual spin crossover (Figure ), with χm T decreasing from 1.44 cm3 mol–1 K at 375 K (μeff = 3.40 μB), consistent with approximately 75% HS, to 0.38 cm3 mol–1 K at 4 K (μeff = 1.74 μB), consistent with being fully LS. At 298 K χm T is 1.06 cm3 mol–1 K, ∼50% HS, so the T 1/2 is approximately room temperature for this complex (as the fully HS state could not be achieved, a χm T value of 2.6 cm3 mol–1 K was used to estimate the T 1/2). The gradual nature of this SCO is consistent with that observed in many other Co­(II) terpyridine derivatives.

cln_elements.clean_text: 2   1H NMR spectra, in d 3MeCN at 400 MHz, of (top to bottom) py-pzpypz and ZnII and FeII complexes. Note: py-pzpypz has low solubility in this solvent.

cln_elements.content: π–π stacking (dashed lines) and NPz–πPz (dotted lines) interactions in [Co­(py-pzpypz)2]­(BF4)2·MeCN·CHCl3 (polymorph 1) with anions and solvent molecules omitted for clarity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  π-π stacking (dashed lines) and NPz-πPz (dotted lines) interactions in [Co(py-pzpypz)2](BF4)2⋅MeCN⋅CHCl3 (polymorph 1) with anions and solvent molecules omitted for clarity.

cln_elements.content: Space filling model of two adjacent molecules of [Zn­(py-pzpypz)2]­(BF4)2·2MeCN highlighting the strong pair of intermolecular NPz–π interactions between N(2) and the N­(24A) ring on the adjacent complex and, by symmetry, between N(24) and the N­(2A) ring.
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  Space filling model of two adjacent molecules of [Zn(py-pzpypz)2](BF4)2⋅2MeCN highlighting the strong pair of intermolecular NPz-π interactions between N(2) and the N(24A) ring on the adjacent complex and, by symmetry, between N(24) and the N(2A) ring.
